Build ID: M20060921-0945  

Steps To Reproduce:
public void launchConfigurationRemoved(ILaunchConfiguration configuration) {				

 configuration.getType(); <-- throws an exception.					
	}

the exception is:

org.eclipse.debug.core.DebugException: Launch configuration hiberggnate (3) at C:\work\documents\presentations\jbw-berlin\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.debug.core\.launches\hiberggnate (3).launch does not exist.
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchManager.createDebugException(LaunchManager.java:778)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchManager.getInfo(LaunchManager.java:1175)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.getInfo(LaunchConfiguration.java:356)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.getType(LaunchConfiguration.java:487)

Either the implementation or the java doc is wrong since it states handle-only methods are ok to call in the remove listener.

More information:

That is true, handle only methods are safe to call, BUT the doc also states: * A launch configuration is a handle to its underlying storage. * Methods annotated as "handle-only" do not require a configuration * to exist. Methods that require an underlying configuration to exist * throw a CoreException when an underlying configuration * is missing. where getType(..) is a handle only method that does require the configuration to exist (as is doc'd). Only handle-only attributes of a launch configuration are available once it has been removed, not access to its underlying storage. A simple fix for this on your end would be to use the method ILaunchConfiguration.exists(), before calling handle-only methods. marking as WONTFIX

My problem is that how else can one see if the LaunchConfiguration that is being removed is relevant or not for the code ?

The type is a unique id, but the only other info I apparently can get is the name, but that is definitly not unique nor a way to identify the launchconfiguration.

The namespace for launch configurations is flat so the name is sufficient to uniquely identify the configuration.

You can also do a launchconfig.equals(anotherconfig).

The name is sufficient to identify it, but not to know the details of what's in it. 

Perhaps you could have a pre-deletion listener in the model instead of merely post-deletion? That way the user could see the entire configuration, its attributes, etc, before it gets clobbered adn deleted?

Or are you suggesting users keep a duplicate model of the launch configurations and their attributes, in sync, just in case the config is eventually deleted?
my usecase would just benefit from knowing what type it is so i could avoid doing a possible expensive lookup to see if I need to clean something up after the removal.
